questions.text: Which statement best describes the necessity of switching from trivalent oral polio vaccine (tOPV) to bivalent oral polio vaccine (bOPV) as part of the Polio Eradication and Endgame Strategic Plan?

options.label: A
options.text: tOPV was associated with a high incidence of wild poliovirus type 2 (WPV2).

options.label: B
options.text: bOPV was more cost-effective than tOPV for routine immunisation systems.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of cVDPV-circulatory vaccine derived polio virus linked to the type 2 component of OPV outweighed its benefits.

options.label: D
options.text: bOPV was more effective in providing immunity against all three poliovirus types than tOPV.

questions.correct_answer: C. The risk of cVDPV-circulatory vaccine derived polio virus linked to the type 2 component of OPV outweighed its benefits.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an objective of The Polio Eradication Strategy 2022-2026?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent interruption of polio transmission in Pakistan and Afghanistan

questions.correct_answer: D. Rehabilitation of the ones affected

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with sudden onset paralysis of the right leg for 2 weeks with loss of tone and deep tendon reflexes; the leg appeared floppy with no sensory loss. Which of the following is NOT a diagnosis?
The stool specimen for investigation of an acute flaccid paralysis case is transported using which method?

Which of the following statements regarding polio surveillance indicators is correct? At least 80% of expected routine AFP surveillance reports should be received on time, including zero reports where no AFP cases are seen. The sensitivity of surveillance requires detecting at least two cases of non-polio AFP annually per 100,000 population aged less than 15 years in endemic regions. Completeness of case investigation mandates that all AFP cases must have three stool specimens collected within 7 days of paralysis onset. Laboratory performance standards dictate that AFP case specimens must be processed in any accredited clinical laboratory within the country.
questions.explanation:
Indicator

Description

Completeness of reporting

At least 80% of expected routine AFP surveillance reports are to be received on time, including zero reports(no AFP cases seen).

Sensitivity of surveillance

Detect at least one case of non-polio AFP annually per 100,000 population aged <15 years (two per 100,000 in endemic regions).(operational efficiency-non polio AFP rate)

Completeness of case investigation

All AFP cases undergo full clinical and virological investigation with at least 80% of cases having adequate stool specimens collected and transported properly.

Completeness of follow-up

At least 80% of AFP cases receive a follow-up examination for residual paralysis at 60 days post-onset.

Laboratory performance

AFP case specimens are processed in WHO-accredited laboratories within the Global Polio Laboratory Network (GPLN).

questions.text: What best describes the "mopping up" strategy in polio eradication efforts?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves routine immunization activities in all districts to maintain high population immunity.

options.label: B
options.text: It focuses on mass vaccination campaigns conducted in areas where wild poliovirus is known or suspected to be circulating.

options.label: C
options.text: It refers to surveillance activities aimed at detecting cases of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) for prompt response.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves educational campaigns to raise awareness about the importance of polio vaccination among healthcare workers.

questions.correct_answer: B. It focuses on mass vaccination campaigns conducted in areas where wild poliovirus is known or suspected to be circulating.
